description: Food laws and regulations, regulatory and commerical grading standards used in the food industry.

name: THE MICROBIOME OF PLANTS, ANIMALS, AND HUMANS
subject: Animal Sciences
description: Examination of the structure and function of microbial communities that live inside and on host organisms (plants, animals, and humans). Introduction to general concepts of the microbiome and microbiota, and their relationship to host nutrition, health, and disease.
requisite: Requisites: MICROBIO101 or 303 or graduate/professional standing

name: ANIMAL GROWTH AND DEVELOPMENT
subject: Animal Sciences
description: Covers growth and development of an animal from a single cell to an organism and factors such as nutrition, hormone, genetics and gut microbials influencing growth and development in both cell and tissue levels. Includes the molecular and cellular basis of prenatal and postnatal growth and development. Focuses on development and growth of tissues including muscle, adipose, connective, mammary, and bone tissues that are associated with animal production. Also includes the use of growth promotants in livestock to improve growth performance and increase the quality of carcasses and animal production.

name: INTRODUCTION TO ANIMAL AND VETERINARY GENETICS
subject: Animal Sciences
description: The molecular basis for inheritance of monogenic and polygenic traits related to animal disease and production. An introduction to the principles of improving animal health and performance by selection and mating systems in companion animals, horses, livestock, and poultry.
requisite: Requisites: ZOOLOGY/BIOLOGY/BOTANY152, (ZOOLOGY/BIOLOGY101 and 102) or (BIOCORE382, 383, and 384) or graduate/professional standing

name: VETERINARY GENETICS
subject: Animal Sciences
description: The genetic basis for predisposition to diseasse or resistance to disease in livestock and companion animal species. Genetic defects, their discovery, diagnosis and treament.

name: PRINCIPLES OF ANIMAL BREEDING
subject: Animal Sciences
description: Application of the principles of quantitative genetics to the improvement of livestock and poultry; breeding value estimation and selection techniques; effects of inbreeding and hybrid vigor; crossbreeding systems.

name: CONCEPTS IN GENOMICS
subject: Animal Sciences
description: Genomics has revolutionized many fields of science, including animal breeding, plant breeding, physiology, microbiology, and human medicine. A basic overview of the latest concepts in genomics, including 3D genome organization, the importance of genome annotation, the use of genomic testing in plant and animal breeding, the potential of genomic prediction on human medicine, and the latest advances in omics integration.
requisite: Requisites: Junior Standing and BOTANY/BIOLOGY/ZOOLOGY152, (BIOLOGY/ZOOLOGY101, 102, and BIOLOGY/BOTANY130), BIOCORE381, or graduate/professional standing

name: ANIMAL PHYSIOLOGY
subject: Animal Sciences
description: Covers physiological processes that regulate the body and the anatomy and function of different physiological systems. Includes interactions between organ systems, analysis of a single organ system from the molecular to the organismal, and comparisons and contrasts of organ systems among different domestic animal species.

name: SPECIAL TOPICS
subject: Animal Sciences
description: Various topics in Animal Science of current interest to undergraduate students.

name: COORDINATIVE INTERNSHIP/COOPERATIVE EDUCATION
subject: Animal Sciences
description: An internship under guidance of a faculty or instructional academic staff member in Animal and Dairy Sciences and internship site supervisor. Students are responsible for arranging the work and credits with the faculty or instructional academic staff member and the internship site supervisor.

name: STUDY ABROAD IN ANIMAL SCIENCES
subject: Animal Sciences
description: Provides an area equivalency for courses taken on Madison Study Abroad Programs that do not equate to existing UW courses.

name: APPLICATION OF MONOGASTRIC NUTRITION PRINCIPLES
subject: Animal Sciences
description: Nutrient requirements for growth and production of monogastric animals. Discuss concepts of establishing nutrient requirements and feeding strategies. Laboratory exercises are designed to develop problem solving skills required for the assessment of nutritional adequacy and economical soundness of feeding programs.
requisite: Requisites: DYSCI/ANSCI/NUTRSCI311, (BIOCHEM301 or 501) or graduate/professional standing

name: BEEF CATTLE PRODUCTION
subject: Animal Sciences
description: Application of genetics, systems of mating, physiology, nutrition and economics to the production of beef.
requisite: Requisites: NUTRSCI/ANSCI/DYSCI311, DYSCI/ANSCI361, and (DYSCI/ANSCI434 or concurrent registration) or graduate/professional standing

name: SWINE PRODUCTION
subject: Animal Sciences
description: Application of research findings in breeding, feeding, management and marketing to modernize production. Lab may include farm visits, practical exercises in testing changes, and "tools" used by producers.
requisite: Requisites: NUTRSCI/ANSCI/DYSCI311, DYSCI/ANSCI361, DYSCI/ANSCI434, or graduate/professional standing

name: REPRODUCTIVE PHYSIOLOGY
subject: Animal Sciences
description: Principles of reproductive physiology, improvement of fertility, and artificial insemination.
requisite: Requisites: ZOOLOGY/BIOLOGY/BOTANY152, (ZOOLOGY/BIOLOGY101 and 102) or (BIOCORE382, 383, and 384) or graduate/professional standing

name: ANIMAL SCIENCES PROSEMINAR
subject: Animal Sciences
description: Methods of assessing information quality are studied. Each student develops an analytical and critical seminar on a topic of personal interest in the animal sciences.

name: ANIMAL AGRICULTURE AND GLOBAL SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT
subject: Animal Sciences
description: Examines issues related to global agriculture and healthy sustainable development. Using a regional approach and focusing on crops and livestock case studies, students will learn the interdependence between US agriculture and agriculture in emerging economies. Some topics covered include population and food, immigration, the environment; crop and livestock agriculture; global trade; sustainability; food security, the role of women in agriculture, and the role of dairy products in a healthy diet.

name: INTERNATIONAL FIELD STUDY IN ANIMAL AGRICULTURE AND SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT
subject: Animal Sciences
description: Examines issues related to global agriculture and healthy sustainable development. Using a regional approach and focusing on crops and livestock case studies, students will learn the interdependence between US agriculture and agriculture in emerging economies. Some topics covered include population and food, immigration, the environment; crop and livestock agriculture; global trade; sustainability; and the role of women in agriculture and the role of dairy products in a healthy diet.

name: POULTRY PRODUCTS TECHNOLOGY
subject: Animal Sciences
description: Procurement, processing and distribution of poultry meat, eggs and derived products; factors affecting quality, including methods of determining quality.

name: BREEDER FLOCK AND HATCHERY MANAGEMENT
subject: Animal Sciences
description: History of artificial incubation relevant to the U.S. hatching industry. Practices involved in successful incubation of hatching eggs. Embryonic development in birds. Management factors involved in breeder hen production and operating a hatchery.

name: MANAGEMENT FOR AVIAN HEALTH
subject: Animal Sciences
description: The occurrence, etiology, clinical signs, control and prevention of infectious and noninfectious diseases commonly affecting domestically reared poultry. Instruction in avian necropsy, zoonosis, sanitation and regulation.

name: COMMERCIAL MEAT PROCESSING
subject: Animal Sciences
description: Principles and procedures in the commercial manufacture of processed meat products; sausage manufacturing, curing, smoking, freezing and packaging.
requisite: Requisites: ANSCI/FOODSCI305, FOODSCI410, or graduate/professional standing

name: ORNITHOLOGY
subject: Animal Sciences
description: Introduction to bird biology, ecology, and behavior. Topics include the evolutionary origin of birds and flight, anatomy and physiology, functional morphology, migration, communication, reproductive strategies, ecological adaptations and roles, and biogeographical patterns.
requisite: Requisites: ZOOLOGY/BIOLOGY101 and 102, ZOOLOGY/BIOLOGY/BOTANY152, (BIOCORE381 and 382), or graduate/professional standing

name: BIRDS OF SOUTHERN WISCONSIN
subject: Animal Sciences
description: Outdoor and indoor labs/lectures emphasizing identification of southern Wisconsin birds by sight and vocalization. Two required Saturday field trips in Southern Wisconsin.
requisite: Requisites: ZOOLOGY/BIOLOGY101 and 102, ZOOLOGY/BIOLOGY/BOTANY152, (BIOCORE381 and 382), or graduate/professional standing

name: QUANTITATIVE GENETICS
subject: Animal Sciences
description: An advanced approach with emphasis on statistical foundations. Classical theory with extensions to maternal and paternal effects. Selection theory is considered in depth.

name: GENETIC MAPPING
subject: Animal Sciences
description: Computing-intensive course to prepare students for genetic mapping research; linkage analysis and QTL mapping in designed crosses; linkage disequilibrium and association analysis (GWAS). Recommended preparation is undergraduate courses in genetics and statistics and prior experience writing R scripts (such as module 1 of STAT327).

name: EXPERIMENTAL DIET DESIGN
subject: Animal Sciences
description: Discuss nutrient requirements, composition of ingredients used to meet requirements and the mathematical steps involved in diet formulation with emphasis on research animals and human subjects.

name: SENIOR HONOR THESIS
subject: Animal Sciences
description: Individual study for majors completing theses for Honors degrees as arranged with a faculty member.

name: SENIOR HONORS THESIS
subject: Animal Sciences
description: Second semester of individual study for majors completing theses for Honors degrees as arranged with a faculty member.

name: THESIS
subject: Animal Sciences
description: Individual study for majors completing theses as arranged with a faculty member.

name: THESIS
subject: Animal Sciences
description: Second semester of individual study for majors completing theses as arranged with a faculty member.

name: CHEMISTRY OF THE FOOD LIPIDS
subject: Animal Sciences
description: Chemical constitution, structures, reactions, stereochemistry of fats, phospholipids, related compounds; methods of isolation, characterization; synthesis; relation of structure to physical properties.

name: PRACTICUM IN ANIMAL SCIENCES TEACHING
subject: Animal Sciences
description: Instructional orientation to teaching at the higher education level in the agricultural and life sciences, direct teaching experience under faculty supervision, experience in testing and evaluation of students, and the analysis of teaching performance.

name: RUMINANT NUTRITIONAL PHYSIOLOGY I
subject: Animal Sciences
description: Focuses on rumen microbiology, metabolite modeling, as well as protein and VFA nutrition and metabolism.

name: RUMINANT NUTRITIONAL PHYSIOLOGY II
subject: Animal Sciences
description: Focuses on calf and heifer nutrition, regulation of dry matter intake, plant and forage chemistry, vitamins, lipids, and starch.

name: GENETIC EPIDEMIOLOGY
subject: Animal Sciences
description: This course will provide an introduction to genetic epidemiology. Topics will include a general overview of genetics and Mendelian and complex inheritance, as well as various elements of study design, including participant ascertainment; phenotype definition; biologic sample selection; genotyping, sequencing, and quality control; measurement of covariates, and choice of analytic methods. We will briefly discuss some of the original study designs and then focus on current study designs for the remainder of the class. Additional emerging topics will be briefly touched upon. Students will complete short homework assignments to enforce concepts learned during lectures, discuss journal articles, and prepare a very short grant application for the mid-term project. In the final weeks of class, students will work together to analyze data from a real genetic study, prepare tables, interpret the findings, and present their project to their peers.

name: DESIGN AND ANALYSIS OF BIOLOGICAL STUDIES
subject: Animal Sciences
description: Experimental design and proper data analysis are critical processes for scientific research. Planning and performing research studies have statistical implications that influence how results are interpreted. Learn the fundamentals of generalized linear models, experimental design, and data analysis using common examples from biological studies.

name: SEMINAR IN ANIMAL NUTRITION
subject: Animal Sciences
description: Discussion of literature that has a bearing on animal nutrition. Students are to survey the literature and present a seminar.

name: SEMINAR IN ENDOCRINOLOGY-REPRODUCTIVE PHYSIOLOGY
subject: Animal Sciences
description: Promotes scientific and professional development. Presenters develop and deliver research presentations to a scientific audience, field questions, and receive critiques about their presentation style and scientific approach. Additional presentations include professional development, career advancement opportunities, and topics of interest to the endocrinology and reproduction community at large.

name: RESEARCH
subject: Animal Sciences
description: Independent research in preparation of a graduate thesis under supervision of a faculty member.

name: GENERAL ANTHROPOLOGY
subject: Anthropology
description: General understanding of humans in relation to cultures, evolutionary development and racial diversity, capacities for society, and the development of the world's major cultures.

name: ARCHAEOLOGY AND THE PREHISTORIC WORLD
subject: Anthropology
description: Introduction to the ancient world from origins of human culture to the beginnings of written history as revealed by archaeological research at great sites and ruins around the globe. Archaeological analyses of important sites as case studies to illustrate concepts and techniques used by archaeologists in their efforts to understand the diversity of the human past.

name: CULTURAL ANTHROPOLOGY AND HUMAN DIVERSITY
subject: Anthropology
description: Introduction to cultural anthropology. Comparative cross-cultural consideration of social organization, economics, politics, language, religion, ecology, gender, and cultural change. Includes a primary focus on U.S. ethnic and racial minorities.

name: PRINCIPLES OF BIOLOGICAL ANTHROPOLOGY
subject: Anthropology
description: Genetic basis of morphological, physiological and behavioral variations within and between human populations, and their origins and evolution.

name: FRESHMAN/SOPHOMORE SEMINAR IN ANTHROPOLOGY
subject: Anthropology
description: Intensive study of a problem in human variability through study of nontechnical materials. Emphasis on acquiring anthropological concepts through discussion and direct experience of ethnographic, archaeological, or human physical evidence.

name: GLOBAL LANGUAGE ISSUES
subject: Anthropology
description: Focuses on language and its culture, example topics include: extinction and revival, language and nationhood, how widely and deeply languages differ, language and worldview, writing systems and literacy, language discrimination and inequality.

name: PRINCIPLES OF ARCHAEOLOGY
subject: Anthropology
description: Introduction to the methods, historical development, and scientific principles of archaeology. Discover how archaeologists generate and interpret information about the human past. Introduces scientific inquiry and provides a foundation for pursuing advanced archaeological courses and field research.

name: INTRODUCTION TO SOCIAL MEDICINE
subject: Anthropology
description: Provides analytical tools for the critical examination of the social, cultural, political and economic determinants of health conditions and medical practice. Pays special attention to how these factors determine how patients and providers experience and ideate disease and treatment, and how they respond to specific health care policies. Emphasizes the important role that conditions of structural violence and inequality play as determinants of health conditions in a globalized world.

name: CUT 'N' MIX: MUSIC, RACE, AND CULTURE IN THE CARIBBEAN
subject: Anthropology
description: Explores the history and culture of the Caribbean by focusing on its musics, both religious and secular. Special attention will be directed to the impact of colonialism on the emergence of racially stratified societies. Music will also enable us to investigate the concepts of diaspora and creolization. Other topics include: gender and sexuality, the role of technology in the production and distribution of music, music and politics, the impact of tourism, and the global impact of Caribbean musics.

name: LATIN AMERICA: AN INTRODUCTION
subject: Anthropology
description: Latin American culture and society from an interdisciplinary perspective; historical developments from pre-Columbian times to the present; political movements; economic problems; social change; ecology in tropical Latin America; legal systems; literature and the arts; cultural contrasts involving the US and Latin America; land reform; labor movements; capitalism, socialism, imperialism; mass media.

name: DIMENSIONS OF MATERIAL CULTURE
subject: Anthropology
description: This course introduces students to the interdisciplinary field of material culture studies. It is intended for students interested in any professional endeavor related to material culture, including careers in museums, galleries, historical societies, historic preservation organizations, and academic institutions. During the semester, students have varied opportunities to engage with and contemplate the material world to which people give meaning and which, in turn, influences their lives. Sessions combine in some way the following: presentations from faculty members and professionals who lecture on a phase of material culture related to his/her own scholarship or other professional work; discussion of foundational readings in the field; visits to collections and sites on campus and around Madison; discussion of readings assigned by visiting presenters or the professors; and exams and short papers that engage material culture topics.

name: INTRODUCTION TO CULTURE AND HEALTH
subject: Anthropology
description: Uses the conceptual tools of anthropology to explore how culture, biology, and power together shape the ways people are born, experience good and poor health, seek therapeutic aid, and die. Draws on material from around the world, with a particular focus on the experience of marginalized minority people in the United States.

name: AFRICA: AN INTRODUCTORY SURVEY
subject: Anthropology
description: African society and culture, polity and economy in multidisciplinary perspectives from prehistory and ancient kingdoms through the colonial period to contemporary developments, including modern nationalism, economic development and changing social structure.

name: CULTURAL ANTHROPOLOGY: THEORY AND ETHNOGRAPHY
subject: Anthropology
description: Survey of cultural anthropology with emphasis on ethnographic description, methodology, and contemporary theories. Focuses on humanistic and social scientific approaches to human sociocultural diversity.

name: INTRODUCTION TO LINGUISTICS: DESCRIPTIVE AND THEORETICAL
subject: Anthropology
description: Elementary theory and practical work in phonetics, phonology, morphology, and syntax, with attention to formal grammar.
requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing. Not open to students with credit for LINGUIS101.

name: HOMINOID EVOLUTION
subject: Anthropology
description: The evolution of the Hominoidea is reconstructed from direct and indirect evidence. Cladistic and phylogenetic analyses are used to study the relationships among species. Interpretations of the fossil record are presented from a historical perspective, focusing on the hominoid-hominid transition.

name: HUMAN SKELETAL ANATOMY
subject: Anthropology
description: A comprehensive examination of skeletal anatomy at both the gross and histologic levels. Utilizes laboratory methods for the archaeological identification of skeletal fragments; criteria for the estimation of age, sex, stature, and other aspects of forensicanthropology.

name: HEREDITY, ENVIRONMENT AND HUMAN POPULATIONS
subject: Anthropology
description: Cultural and ecological factors influencing the composition and structure of human populations; variation and distribution of genes within and between populations; history and evolution of human populations as evidenced by genomes.
requisite: Requisites: ANTHRO105, ZOOLOGY/BIOLOGY/BOTANY152,  ZOOLOGY/BIOLOGY101, F&WECOL/ENVIRST/ZOOLOGY360, BIOCORE382, ZOOLOGY/BOTANY/ENVIRST260, ZOOLOGY/ANTHRO/BOTANY410, or graduate/professional standing

name: URBAN ANTHROPOLOGY
subject: Anthropology
description: An integrated anthropological view of the city and urbanization as a human and cultural phenomenon, including major theories and concrete data from both 'first', 'second' and 'third' worlds, emphasizing the continuity of urban development from the first cities until now.

name: TOPICS IN ARCHAEOLOGY
subject: Anthropology
description: Selected areas, periods or problems in archaeology.

name: INDIANS OF NORTH AMERICA
subject: Anthropology
description: Description and analysis of native cultures, and the role of environmental and historical factors in North America.

name: THE EMERGENCE OF HUMAN CULTURE
subject: Anthropology
description: Worldwide archaeological evidence for the development of human culture and behavior from the earliest appearance of human groups to the threshold of the agricultural revolution.

name: THE ORIGINS OF CIVILIZATION
subject: Anthropology
description: Global archaeological survey of the origins of pristine civilizations beginning with the development of food production and ending with the emergence of the world's first civilizations. Focus of attention: Near East, Egypt, the Indus Valley, North China, Mesoamerica, and Peru.

name: TOPICS IN ETHNOLOGY
subject: Anthropology
description: Content varies. Some representative topics: peoples and cultures of the European part of the USSR, peoples and cultures of Soviet Asia, anthropology of space and time, anthropology and history, pastoralists and pastoral Nomads, American Indian folklore, etc.

name: PREHISTORY OF AFRICA
subject: Anthropology
description: A survey of the archaeological record of human development in Africa, beginning over two million years ago and continuing through the transition to farming and metallurgy; greatest emphasis on the stone age portion of prehistory.

name: LITHICS AND ARCHAEOLOGY
subject: Anthropology
description: Explores the ways in which humans have used of rocks and associated minerals, i.e. lithics and lapidary technology, to create utilitarian as well as ornamental objects in the past and the present.  Explores gender roles in lithic technology and how specific technologies were used to create utilitarian as well as ornamental and symbolic objects. Gain a new perspective of the critical role of lithic technologies in long term human adaptive strategies as well as in ornament and symbolic art.

name: ARCHAEOLOGY OF WARFARE AND HUMAN NATURE
subject: Anthropology
description: Introduction to the evidence, debates, and theories related to violence and warfare in the human past, and how related behaviors are linked to the evolution of our species and modern manifestations of war. Highlights archaeological methods that recognize past warfare practices. Using case studies from the Pleistocene to the present, explores variations of warfare from all over the world. Topics considered include 1) the highly variable nature of violence and warfare in different cultural settings; 2) the antiquity of warfare; 3) how violence has shaped human societies. Historical and cross-cultural ethnographic research will be juxtaposed against archaeological cases to provide contextualized and data-rich examinations. Learn to critically evaluate arguments, claims, and interpretations made about war, peace, and human nature.

name: MUSIC, RACE, AND CULTURE IN BRAZIL
subject: Anthropology
description: Focuses on music's significant role in the formation and maintenance of Brazilian national identity. Learn how a variety of Brazilian individuals, groups, and institutions have contributed to popular and scholarly debates about Brazilian culture, identity, and forms of belonging. These discussions will be anchored to important themes in Brazil's recent history, present, and imagined future, such as cultural cannibalism (antropofagia), and racial hybridity (mestiçagem). Gain insight into how Brazilian artists and their audiences have debated race and racism through expressive means by analyzing a variety of anthropological and ethnomusicological texts about Brazilian popular music, literature, and its most famous annual ritual, Carnival.

name: ANTHROPOLOGY OF RELIGION
subject: Anthropology
description: Anthropological approaches. Illustrated by critical considerations of outstanding contributions. Selected religious systems; areal and topical comparative studies; religion as an ethnographic problem.

name: FAMILY, KIN AND COMMUNITY IN ANTHROPOLOGICAL PERSPECTIVE
subject: Anthropology
description: Comparison of the form and function of such social institutions as marriage and the family, age and sex groups, secret societies, task groups, and class in cross-cultural perspective.

name: ECONOMIC ANTHROPOLOGY
subject: Anthropology
description: Production, distribution and consumption in a broad range of societies; land tenure and personal property concepts, prestige systems, and incentives to labor.

name: POLITICAL ANTHROPOLOGY
subject: Anthropology
description: Comparison and analysis of political structures, behavior and processes among selected peoples of the world; special emphasis on leadership, authority, power, and the origins of the states; the relevance of primitive political systems to anthropological theory and to the comparative study of politics.

name: ANCIENT TECHNOLOGY AND INVENTION
subject: Anthropology
description: The origins and development of early technologies. Impact of key prehistoric and pre-industrial inventions on the course of human evolution.

name: ARCHAEOLOGY OF WISCONSIN
subject: Anthropology
description: Introduction to the archaeological evidence for the diverse Native American cultures of Wisconsin over the past 12,000 years.

name: INTRODUCTION TO THE ANTHROPOLOGY OF JAPAN
subject: Anthropology
description: Japanese culture from anthropological perspectives. Emphasis on the order of meaning which serves both as model for and model of the day-to-day behavior and thought processes of the Japanese.

name: ANTHROPOLOGY OF CHINA
subject: Anthropology
description: Topics of immediate concern to the field of anthropology and Chinese studies. Focus on social and cultural changes in rural, urban, as well as ethnic minority settings in post-1949 China.

name: ELEMENTARY QUECHUA
subject: Anthropology
description: Phonology and morphology; concentration on the acquisition of conversational skills; reading of texts of graded difficulty.

name: ELEMENTARY QUECHUA
subject: Anthropology
description: Continued introduction to phonology and morphology; concentration on the acquisition of conversational skills; reading of texts of graded difficulty.

name: INTERMEDIATE QUECHUA
subject: Anthropology
description: Advanced morphology and syntax; advanced conversation and composition; cultural background of Quechua speaking peoples through reading of myths, legends and folktales.

name: ADVANCED QUECHUA
subject: Anthropology
description: Continuation of advanced conversation and composition; cultural background of Quechua-speaking peoples through reading of myths, legends, folktales; problems in dialectology.

name: MEDICAL ANTHROPOLOGY
subject: Anthropology
description: The ecology of health and disease in human cultures; health-related social systems and behavior cross-culturally; practical implications of medical anthropology for improving the health of specific populations.

name: FIELD COURSE IN ARCHAEOLOGY
subject: Anthropology
description: An introduction to the techniques of field archaeology, including site survey, mapping, and excavation by participation in an actual, off-campus archaeological field project. Also instruction in the description and analysis of artifacts. Includes full-time, off-campus, on-site excavation work, which typically takes place outside of Madison. Excavation sites vary.

name: FIRST SEMESTER YUCATEC MAYA
subject: Anthropology
description: Introduction to Yucatec Maya language. Focus on acquiring  vocabulary and grammar for basic conversational proficiency. Taught through in-class oral and aural exercises, language tapes, and primary texts. Learn about Maya culture, history, folklore, and language politics.

name: SECOND SEMESTER YUCATEC MAYA
subject: Anthropology
description: Continued introduction to Yucatec Maya language. Focus on acquiring  vocabulary and grammar for basic conversational proficiency. Taught through in-class oral and aural exercises, language tapes, and primary texts. Learn about Maya culture, history, folklore, and language politics.

name: BONES FOR THE ARCHAEOLOGIST
subject: Anthropology
description: An introduction to the principles and techniques in the identification and interpretation of animal bones. Includes analysis of an archaeological bone assemblage.

name: INTRODUCTION TO MUSEUM STUDIES IN ANTHROPOLOGY
subject: Anthropology
description: Provides a comprehensive understanding of the policies, procedures, and ethics pertaining to the development, management, and exhibition of anthropology collections. This includes an overview of the establishment, history, and laws governing anthropology collections and collections management methods used specifically for archaeological artifacts, ethnographic objects, and bioanthropological specimens. Ideal for those interested in natural history museums, museum studies, or the museum profession.

name: EVOLUTIONARY BIOLOGY
subject: Anthropology
description: Evolutionary biology, emphasizing how modern scientists study evolution. Topics include: nature and mechanisms of microevolution, macroevolution, adaptation, speciation; systematics and taxonomy; quantitative genetics and measurement of natural selection; phylogenetic analyses of behavior, physiology, morphology, biochemistry; current controversies in evolution.
requisite: Requisites: ZOOLOGY/BIOLOGY101, BIOLOGY/BOTANY130, ZOOLOGY/BIOLOGY/BOTANY152, BIOCORE381, (ANTHRO105 and satisfied QR-A requirement), or graduate/professional standing

name: THE EVOLUTION OF THE GENUS, HOMO
subject: Anthropology
description: Human evolution beginning with the Pliocene appearance of our genus, Homo, and ending with the worldwide spread of modern Homo sapiens  throughout the world.

name: THE ANTHROPOLOGICAL STUDY OF CHILDREN & YOUTH
subject: Anthropology
description: Uses the conceptual tools of cultural anthropology to explore the wide range of children's and youths' experiences outside of and beyond school.

name: INTRODUCTION TO PRIMATOLOGICAL RESEARCH
subject: Anthropology
description: Supervised research on topics selected by students. Independently design a research project, synthesize methods and empirical results, and report one's findings. Develop the skills necessary for independent research in Primatology.
requisite: Requisites: ANTHRO100, 105, PSYCH450, or graduate/professional standing

name: HISTORICAL ANTHROPOLOGY
subject: Anthropology
description: An introduction to historical approaches in anthropology: topics covered include early theories, evolutionism, ethnohistory, culture change, ritual and symbolic transformation, indigenous/oral histories, conceptions of time and the analysis of texts and visual images.

name: LANGUAGE AND CULTURE
subject: Anthropology
description: The relationship of language as a communication system to the culture transmitted by it. Principle problems in the interrelations of language and nonlinguistic human behavior.

name: AMERICAN INDIAN FOLKLORE
subject: Anthropology
description: An introduction to the genres of American Indian Folklore. Special attention is given to creation stories, trickster tales, and the relationship between folklore and historical memory.
requisite: Requisites: Junior standing and (AMERIND/ANTHRO314, FOLKLORE100, 230, or 320), or graduate/professional standing

name: AMERICAN INDIAN WOMEN
subject: Anthropology
description: Examines and interprets the roles of American Indian women in traditional societies, and in contemporary North America.

name: ANTHROPOLOGY BY WOMEN
subject: Anthropology
description: Contributions of women anthropologists to feminist and anthropological theories and research methods. Field research and gender. Current debates in women's studies and anthropology in light of recent research on women and gender in cross-cultural perspective.

name: ANTHROPOLOGY OF LAW
subject: Anthropology
description: A comparative examination of the legal realm of tribal and peasant societies as seen in cross-cultural perspective. Describes the relationship of law to anthropology, presents theories of change of legal systems and provides ethnographic case studies.

name: STUDY ABROAD: TOPICS IN ARCHAEOLOGY
subject: Anthropology
description: A course carried with a UW-Madison study abroad program which has no equivalent on this campus. Enrollment in a UW-Madison resident study abroad program

name: STUDY ABROAD: TOPICS IN BIOLOGICAL ANTHROPOLOGY
subject: Anthropology
description: A course carried with a UW-Madison study abroad program which has no equivalent on this campus. Enrollment in a UW-Madison resident study abroad program

name: SYMBOLIC ANTHROPOLOGY
subject: Anthropology
description: The study of society through the analysis of symbolic systems. Myth, cosmology, ritual, political symbolism, the symbolic study of kinship, symbols and social change.
requisite: Requisites: ANTHRO104 and junior standing, or graduate/professional standing

name: PRIMATE BEHAVIORAL ECOLOGY
subject: Anthropology
description: Primate behavior examined from an evolutionary and ecological perspective, focusing on adaptations to the social and nonsocial environment. Topics include: nepotism, reciprocity, competition, cooperation, sex differences, the ecological role of primates in their communities, cognition, and conservation. Considers the major threats to primates today, and how behavioral adaptations and anthropogenic variables interact to affect the future survival of primates at local, regional, and global scales.
requisite: Requisites: ANTHRO105, ZOOLOGY/BIOLOGY/BOTANY152, ZOOLOGY/BIOLOGY101, (BIOCORE381 and 382), ZOOLOGY/BOTANY/ENVIRST260, ZOOLOGY/ENVIRST/F&WECOL360, PSYCH450, or graduate/professional standing

name: THE ANTHROPOLOGY OF DANCE: MOVEMENT AND MUSIC IN PERFORMANCE
subject: Anthropology
description: Explores the significance of movements, sounds, and the body in the transmission of knowledge, the formation of cultural communities, and the expression of identity. Offers first-hand practical experience of the ethnographic study of dance and movements.

name: ETHNOBOTANY
subject: Anthropology
description: Study of the interactions between human cultures and plants. Topics include: traditional resource management and agriculture; crop domestication, evolution, and conservation; archaeobotany; indigenous knowledge; folk taxonomy; plants in symbolism and religion; dietary patterns; phytochemistry; global movement of plants and peoples.

name: ANTHROPOLOGY, ENVIRONMENT, AND DEVELOPMENT
subject: Anthropology
description: Identifies and examines cultural and environmental factors which should be taken into account in planning effective development. Case studies of development programs in less developed countries. Possible contributions of anthropologists and environmental scientists in planning, implementing, and evaluating development programs.

name: UNDERGRADUATE SEMINAR
subject: Anthropology
description: Discussion and preparation of reports on specific topics indicated by changing title of seminar.
requisite: Requisites: Junior standing and declared in the Anthropology undergraduate program or Archaeology undergraduate certificate

name: ETHNIC REPRESENTATIONS IN WISCONSIN
subject: Anthropology
description: Representation and self-representation of ethnic cultures in Wisconsin. For example: museums, mass media, ethnic theater.
requisite: Requisites: ANTHRO300, FOLKLORE100, GNS/FOLKLORE200, or graduate/professional standing

name: THE FOLKLORE OF FESTIVALS AND CELEBRATIONS
subject: Anthropology
description: Survey of interdisciplinary literature on social/performative folklore aesthetics and environments by in-depth study of three festivals and ceremonies. Required field trips.

name: PSYCHOLOGICAL ANTHROPOLOGY
subject: Anthropology
description: Survey of psychologically oriented approaches in cultural anthropology: ethnopsychiatry, the ethnography of emotion, conceptions of the self, cognitive development, and culturally defined deviance and mental illness.

name: ANTHROPOLOGY AND EDUCATION
subject: Anthropology
description: An exploration of the foundational concepts and methods of educational anthropology. Examines anthropological inquiry on educational research with particular reference to cultural perspectives on education and educational systems, learning as cultural transmission, and application of anthropological knowledge to curriculum.

name: PROSEMINAR IN BIOLOGICAL ANTHROPOLOGY
subject: Anthropology
description: Overview of the major theoretical developments and debates in biological anthropology and their relevance to both historical and current research.

name: SEMINAR IN EVOLUTIONARY THEORY
subject: Anthropology
description: Examination of theory relevant to the evolution of humans and nonhuman primates including morphological, behavioral, and genetic aspects.
requisite: Requisites: ANTHRO105, ZOOLOGY/BIOLOGY/BOTANY152,  ZOOLOGY/BIOLOGY101, F&WECOL/ENVIRST/ZOOLOGY360, BIOCORE382, ZOOLOGY/BOTANY/ENVIRST260, ZOOLOGY/ANTHRO/BOTANY410, or graduate/professional standing

name: SEMINAR-CURRENT PROBLEMS IN PALEOANTHROPOLOGY
subject: Anthropology
description: Current research with attention to the evolutionary biology of humans and fossil human relatives.
requisite: Requisites: ANTHRO105, ZOOLOGY/BIOLOGY/BOTANY152,  ZOOLOGY/BIOLOGY101, F&WECOL/ENVIRST/ZOOLOGY360, BIOCORE382, ZOOLOGY/BOTANY/ENVIRST260, ZOOLOGY/ANTHRO/BOTANY410, or graduate/professional standing

name: ETHNICITY, NATIONS, AND NATIONALISM
subject: Anthropology
description: Analytical treatment of current anthropological approaches to the study of ethnicity, nation, and nationalism accompanied by case studies.

name: BIOLOGY OF MIND
subject: Anthropology
description: Origins and structures of mind, brain, and consciousness. Transitions from early mammalian through primate to hominid intelligence. Genetics and plasticity in brain development. Modern studies of human brain mechanisms and consciousness.

name: PRIMATE CONSERVATION
subject: Anthropology
description: Evaluates the conservation status of non-human primates, and considers why different species are vulnerable to different kinds of threats. The ways in which regional and global conservation policies are developed and implemented will also be discussed.
requisite: Requisites: ANTHRO458, PSYCH450, ZOOLOGY/ENVIRST/F&WECOL360, ZOOLOGY/ANTHRO/BOTANY410, ZOOLOGY/BOTANY/F&WECOL460, or graduate/professional standing

name: SENIOR HONORS THESIS
subject: Anthropology
description: Mentored individual research and study for students completing a thesis in an Honors program.

name: SENIOR HONORS THESIS
subject: Anthropology
description: Mentored individual research and study for students completing a thesis in an Honors program.

name: PROBLEMS IN ANTHROPOLOGY
subject: Anthropology
description: Independent research in specific problems in physical anthropology, archaeology, or cultural anthropology; under supervision.
requisite: Requisites: Junior standing and (declared in Anthropology undergraduate program or Archaeology undergraduate certificate), or graduate/professional standing

name: SENIOR THESIS
subject: Anthropology
description: Mentored individual research and study for students completing a senior thesis.

name: SENIOR THESIS
subject: Anthropology
description: Mentored individual research and study for students completing a senior thesis.

name: ARCHAEOLOGICAL METHODS OF CURATION
subject: Anthropology
description: Practicum in the curation of prehistoric stone, bone, and ceramics. Involves handling materials, identification of artifacts, conservation techinques, preparation of materials for storage or display.

name: DIRECTED STUDY
subject: Anthropology
description: Advanced directed study projects as arranged with a faculty member.

name: DIRECTED STUDY
subject: Anthropology
description: Advanced directed study projects as arranged with a faculty member.

name: DIMENSIONS OF MATERIAL CULTURE
subject: Anthropology
description: This course introduces students to the interdisciplinary field of material culture studies. It is intended for students interested in any professional endeavor related to material culture, including careers in museums, galleries, historical societies, historic preservation organizations, and academic institutions. During the semester, students have varied opportunities to engage with and contemplate the material world to which people give meaning and which, in turn, influences their lives. Sessions combine in some way the following: presentations from faculty members and professionals who lecture on a phase of material culture related to his/her own scholarship or other professional work; discussion of foundational readings in the field; visits to collections and sites on campus and around Madison; discussion of readings assigned by visiting presenters or the professors; and exams and short papers that engage material culture topics.

name: HISTORY OF ANTHROPOLOGICAL THEORY
subject: Anthropology
description: Intellectual history of the major theoretical debates and key figures in cultural anthropology up to the 1960's.

name: FUNDAMENTALS OF ANTHROPOLOGICAL THEORY
subject: Anthropology
description: Fundamentals of anthropological thought using a cross-section of basic works in social science. Emphasizes discussion, critical analysis, and development of professional writing skills.

name: METHODS AND HYPOTHESIS-TESTING FOR BEHAVIORAL ECOLOGISTS
subject: Anthropology
description: A detailed overview of field methods for behavioral ecologists, focusing specifically on behavioral and ecological sampling techniques. It addresses the challenging process of situating an empirical study within the context of theoretical paradigms.

name: RESEARCH METHODS AND RESEARCH DESIGN IN CULTURAL ANTHROPOLOGY
subject: Anthropology
description: Theoretical and practical aspects of ethnographic research; history of field research in anthropology; research design issues; writing proposals; the fieldwork experience; methods of field data collection; ethical issues; data interpretation and analysis; writing ethnography.

name: GLOBALIZATION AND TRANSNATIONAL CULTURES
subject: Anthropology
description: Reviewing the current state of anthropological studies of globalization and examining various approaches taken to the subject. Focusing on works that conceptualize and theorize the transnational culture and ethnographies that represent and explore its multiplicity and complexity.

name: ANTHROPOLOGY AND INTERNATIONAL HEALTH
subject: Anthropology
description: Examination of international health issues from the theoretical and methodological perspectives of anthropology. Includes case studies of applied medical anthropology work as well as critical analysis of development initiatives in public health.

name: ANTHROPOLOGY OF GENDER
subject: Anthropology
description: Theoretical and ethnographic approaches to the anthropology of gender, focusing on current works. Topics include sexual inequality, research methods, gender and history, gender and ethnographic writing, cultural constructions of masculinity, sexuality, and gender studies and anthropological theory.

name: SEMINAR: SOCIO-ECONOMIC CHANGE IN UNDERDEVELOPED AREAS
subject: Anthropology
description: Social and economic factors relating to stability, growth, and change in the non-Western areas of the contemporary world.

name: SEMINAR-PROBLEMS IN CULTURAL ANTHROPOLOGY
subject: Anthropology
description: Current anthropological literature and methods. Assigned problems.

name: SEMINAR-ARCHAEOLOGICAL PROBLEMS
subject: Anthropology
description: Current literature and methods and work on assigned problems.

name: SEMINAR IN ANTHROPOLOGY AND EDUCATION
subject: Anthropology
description: Anthropological theory, methodology, and field techniques with specific reference to school ethnography and cross-cultural studies of socialization and education. Topics vary.

name: INTERDEPARTMENTAL SEMINAR IN THE LATIN-AMERICAN AREA
subject: Anthropology
description: Interdisciplinary inquiry in Latin American society and culture.

name: INTERDEPARTMENTAL SEMINAR IN AFRICAN STUDIES TOPICS
subject: Anthropology
description: Interdisciplinary inquiry in African societies and cultures.

name: RESEARCH AND THESIS
subject: Anthropology
description: Advanced level mentored reading and research for students with dissertator status.

name: READING AND RESEARCH
subject: Anthropology
description: Advanced level mentored reading and research for students with dissertator status.

name: PRINCIPLES OF BIOTECHNOLOGY
subject: Applied Biotechnology
description: Principles and techniques pertaining to biotechnology and its applications to our society. Survey of classical and emerging techniques.
requisite: Requisites: Declared in Applied Biotechnology program

name: ETHICS, SAFETY, AND REGULATORY ENVIRONMENTS IN BIOTECHNOLOGY
subject: Applied Biotechnology
description: Ethical and safety concerns in development, production, funding, and application of biotechnology. Analysis of socioeconomic impacts. Understanding the importance of data integrity. Overview of risk assessment and management in a regulatory environment designed to ensure safety of workers, study subjects, and patients, and protect intellectual property, data, and the environment.
requisite: Requisites: Declared in Applied Biotechnology program

name: PROFESSIONAL AND TECHNICAL COMMUNICATION IN BIOTECHNOLOGY
subject: Applied Biotechnology
description: Application and analysis of professional scientific communication, both written and oral. Focuses on designing documents that convey complex, data-rich technical and scientific content to audiences with diverse information needs using a variety of professional genres, including reports, proposals, presentations, and documentation.
requisite: Requisites: Declared in Applied Biotechnology program

name: TECHNIQUES IN BIOTECHNOLOGY
subject: Applied Biotechnology
description: Application of biological and chemical methods to modern biotechnological product development. Overview of analysis techniques used to characterize products and evaluate quality and safety. Exploration of technological pipeline from conception to market, including proof-of-concept assessment, pre-clinical trials, clinical trials, and post-production testing.

name: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN AND ANALYSIS IN BIOTECHNOLOGY
subject: Applied Biotechnology
description: Principles of descriptive and inferential statistics with applications in biotechnology including experimental design, quantitative data analysis, and bioinformatic evaluation of complex molecular and biological data sets.
requisite: Requisites: Declared in MS Applied Biotechnology or Capstone Certificate in Applied Bioinformatics

name: LEADERSHIP IN ORGANIZATIONS
subject: Applied Biotechnology
description: Focuses on strategies and tools that managers use to maximize employee contribution and create organizational excellence. Basic business and leadership principles. Best practices to overcome biases that inhibit organizations and teams from communicating effectively. Examples will come from diverse biotechnology fields, including pharmaceutics, agriculture, and biotechnology services.
requisite: Requisites: Declared in Applied Biotechnology program

name: PYTHON FOR BIOINFORMATICS
subject: Applied Biotechnology
description: Introduce diverse strategies for computational analysis of macromolecular data using Python including sequence alignment, genome annotation, data retrieval from databases, phylogenetic analysis, and molecular evolution. Experiential learning is emphasized; confidence in practical skills is developed through persistent application of course content to projects focused on current problems in bioinformatic research.
requisite: Requisites: Declared in MS Applied Biotechnology or Capstone Certificate in Applied Bioinformatics

name: QUALITY CONTROL AND VALIDATION
subject: Applied Biotechnology
description: Focuses on the importance of quality control and validation in biotechnology product design, development, and manufacturing. Explores quality systems and documentation, global quality standards, and methods for assessing validation including installation, operational, and performance qualifications. Overviews biomanufacturing processes, automation, and ccGMP practices necessary to meet quality standards.

name: REGULATORY PRACTICE AND COMPLIANCE
subject: Applied Biotechnology
description: Identifies and examines the key regulatory agencies and practices that govern the highly regulated and diverse biotechnology industry, both domestically and internationally. Highlights current and emerging FDA and ICH regulations and guidance documents to successfully navigate meeting with the agencies and to submit required documentation for successful product development.

name: INDUSTRIAL APPLICATIONS IN REGULATORY AFFAIRS
subject: Applied Biotechnology
description: Examines the global regulatory environments in risk-based assessment of biotechnological developments across diverse sectors, ensuring consumer and environmental protection. Addresses how validation is essential to the incorporation of emerging technologies into viable, accessible, and successful products. Highlights the stakeholders' role in regulatory oversight and policy through relevant industry case studies.

name: BIOTECHNOLOGY MARKETING AND ENTREPRENEURSHIP
subject: Applied Biotechnology
description: Examines marketing case studies in diverse areas of biotechnology. Addresses marketing fundamentals and strategies, communicating value proposition strategy, ethical and regulatory concerns, startup strategies, pharmaceutical marketing, b2b marketing, salesforce development, branding, and promotion. Culminates with the creation of a marketing plan/analysis.
requisite: Requisites: Declared in Applied Biotechnology program

name: GLOBAL OPERATIONS AND SUPPLY CHAIN MANAGEMENT
subject: Applied Biotechnology
description: Focuses on the strategic importance of operations and supply chain to overall performance relevant to a variety of business processes specific to biotechnology. Topics include production, transportation, distribution systems, sourcing, and purchasing.
requisite: Requisites: Declared in Applied Biotechnology program

name: QUALITY AND PROJECT MANAGEMENT
subject: Applied Biotechnology
description: Quality and project management issues and roles during different phases from RD to market. Introduction to Installation qualification, operation qualification and process qualification (PQ). Project management phases: conceptualizing, planning, executing and closing. Project schedule and time management tools and techniques. Project requirements including quality assurance.

name: ASSESSING INNOVATION IN BIOTECHNOLOGY
subject: Applied Biotechnology
description: A survey of biotechnology assessments in areas such as regenerative medicine, agricultural biotechnology, and bioremediation. Course links disciplines with the critical evaluative role played by scientific discovery, market valuation, intellectual property, freedom-to-operate (FTO), and licensing strategy by assessing the role each played in the commercialization of a specific technology.

name: PRODUCT DEVELOPMENT
subject: Applied Biotechnology
description: Explores strategies in evaluating and implementing new technologies or products in the context of different bioindustries. Identifies considerations in product valuation, feasibility of production, scalability, and supply chain management. Models the process of business growth and innovation through integration of emerging technologies.

name: TOOLS FOR DATA ANALYSIS
subject: Applied Biotechnology
description: Using a variety of existing and emerging bioinformatics tools and computational methods, emphasizes hands-on experiences analyzing and interpreting large data sets (e.g. genomic, proteomic, microbiomics, interactome, target discovery). Evaluate and adapt existing computational approaches for specific use in solving a problem in biotechnology.

name: BIOINFORMATIC INQUIRY
subject: Applied Biotechnology
description: Advances the development of competencies promoting efficient analysis of biological data. Emphasizes matching a research problem with the most effective tools for its completion, balancing use of existing software and de novo software development. Advanced aspects of Python and R, algorithmics, machine learning, simulations, and effective communication of results are emphasized.

name: APPLICATION OF BIOINFORMATICS
subject: Applied Biotechnology
description: Exploration and application of existing bioinformatic tools. Implementation of pre-coded solutions to data acquisition, wrangling, analysis, visualization, and structural modeling problems. Complete a project that generates a multi-system workflow to solve bioinformatic problems.

name: PRE-CAPSTONE
subject: Applied Biotechnology
description: Prepares the student for applied self-directed capstone experience. Addressing problem identification, research, and project formulation. Culminates in an oral and written proposal with project schedule.

name: CAPSTONE
subject: Applied Biotechnology
description: Complete a project (report, business plan, program, etc.) in an area of quality assurance and compliance, business and management, and/or research and development. Culminating in a substantive body of work, executive summary, and reflection. Networking and communication in a professional capacity is expected.

name: INTRODUCTION TO ART
subject: Art Department
description: Seeks answers to the fundamental question "What is art?" Through lectures, readings, discussions, and creative projects, we seek answers from multiple perspectives-historical, theoretical, critical, conceptual, formal, and experiential. Develop visual literacy, sophisticated observational skills and a formal language to assist in the interpretation of objects and experiences in the context of art. Through both theory and practice, develop an understanding of the ways artists arrive at the ideas that inform their creative processes. Includes a survey of developments in art media and looks broadly at art movements, trends and styles throughout history and in varied world cultures.
requisite: Requisites: Not open to students declared in BS-Art, BFA-Art, or BS-Art Ed programs

name: TWO-DIMENSIONAL DESIGN
subject: Art Department
description: Provides an introduction to the fundamentals of two-dimensional design. Develop a clear understanding of visual communication through problem-solving and formal and conceptual experimentation. Learn the elements and principles of design and manipulate those using analog and digital processes. Introduction to the Adobe Creative Suite of products, including InDesign, Illustrator, and (to a lesser degree) Photoshop. Serves as an introduction to professional presentation skills and techniques to hone craftsmanship.

name: THREE-DIMENSIONAL DESIGN
subject: Art Department
description: Applying design principles to 3-D investigations. Lectures, studio exercises, discussions.

name: INTRODUCTION TO DIGITAL FORMS
subject: Art Department
description: An introduction to a range of digital media techniques for artists and designers, including digital imaging, vector graphics, web design and 3D digital modeling.  Emphasis on creative development along with technical skill building.

name: FOUNDATIONS OF CONTEMPORARY ART
subject: Art Department
description: Artists' formal, technical and expressive concerns; the principal ideas of movements which have significantly influenced the major tendencies in contemporary art.

name: DRAWING I
subject: Art Department
description: To develop perceptions, use of perspective, line, light and dark, development of space, and expressive qualities in drawing.

name: DIGITAL PHOTOGRAPHY FOR NON-ART MAJORS
subject: Art Department
description: Introduction to tools, techniques and concepts of digital photography, with an emphasis on the workflow beginning with composition and image capture, to digital manipulation and enhancement, to the end goal of print or online publication. Develop a robust fundamental skill set in digital photography through lectures, readings, discussions, practical instruction, instructor review and group critiques.
requisite: Requisites: Not open to students declared in BS-Art or BFA-Art degrees.

name: CURRENT DIRECTIONS IN ART
subject: Art Department
description: Examination of current artists' motivations, intentions, and processes and their relationship to general developments in contemporary art.

name: DRAWING METHODS & CONCEPTS
subject: Art Department
description: Explore the drawing process through projects that address one or more formal, technical, and/or conceptual issues. The concept of drawing as a vehicle for conveying ideas will be addressed through the study of composition, illusional space, perspective and proportion, and the analysis of form.
requisite: Requisites: ART112, or declared in a BS-Art, BFA-Art, or BS-Art Ed degree program

name: SCULPTURE I
subject: Art Department
description: Introduction to techniques and basic sculpture concepts to provide a survey of sculpture studio practices.

name: INTRODUCTION TO PAINTING
subject: Art Department
description: Introduction to various technical processes and aspects of painting. Studio practice, lectures, discussions, and critiques.

name: CERAMICS I
subject: Art Department
description: Properties of clay and fundamentals of forming; hand-building, throwing, slip-casting, press molding; with emphasis on individual form concepts. Glazing, decorating, firing techniques including reduction, oxidation and primitive methods.

name: TEXTILE DESIGN: OFF-LOOM CONSTRUCTION
subject: Art Department
description: Studio design problems in two and three dimensional off-loom constructions; off-loom weaving, looping, and knotting; historical reference and contemporary application.

name: TEXTILE DESIGN: WEAVING I
subject: Art Department
description: The relationship of hand weaving to textural surfaces and sculptural forms are examined through the study of problems including structure, pattern, composition, and additional conceptual technical possibilities. Content is explored in the development of individual direction and in relationship to the discussion of historical and contemporary textiles and other works of art. Allows students to pursue an advanced investigation of concept and technique of hand-woven cloth.

name: LIFE DRAWING I
subject: Art Department
description: Anatomical structure and intrinsic forms involved in drawing from different models. Development of technical control in a range of media.

name: BASCOM COURSE
subject: Art Department
description: A low-enrollment course developing skills in critical reading, logical thinking, use of evidence, and use of library resources. Emphasis on writing in the conventions of specific fields.

name: WATERCOLOR I
subject: Art Department
description: Painting with watercolor and mixed media on paper. Experimental and traditional uses of the media will be explored, emphasizing drawing, composition, and imagination. Field trips.

name: ART METAL I
subject: Art Department
description: Basic jewelry techniques; metal fabrication dealing with piercing, soldering, forming.

name: COLOR
subject: Art Department
description: Color phenomena and visual perception as applied in art problems. Lectures, readings in theory, philosophy, and history of design.

name: RELIEF PRINTMAKING
subject: Art Department
description: Woodcut, collage print, linoleum cut, and wood engraving; color printing. Studio practice, lectures, discussion, critiques.

name: MAKING COMICS 1
subject: Art Department
description: An introduction to making comics as both a subject and means of academic inquiry. This is a rigorous class and the workload is substantial. Students will learn a variety of ways of making pictures and stories using materials that will vary over the course of the semester. Final project will be an original, reproducible, handmade book of at least 32 pages, based on the stories or comics or characters created during the semester. No previous drawing experience necessary, but must be eager to draw seven days per week throughout the duration of the course.

name: DIGITAL ART AND CODE
subject: Art Department
description: An introduction to the principles of computer coding in a visual context. Course emphasizes the production of graphical and interactive output delivered on a screen.
requisite: Requisites: ART107 or declared in an Art graduate program

name: INTERMEDIATE DRAWING I
subject: Art Department
description: The exploration of conceptual drawing in various media. Emphasis on conceptual/formal solutions.
requisite: Requisites: (ART212, 232, 316, or 326), or declared in an Art graduate program

name: SCULPTURE II
subject: Art Department
description: Continued investigation in sculpture studio practices with an emphasis on developing concepts and technique.
requisite: Requisites: ART214 or declared in an Art graduate program

name: LITHOGRAPHY
subject: Art Department
description: Direct drawing on stone with crayon and tusche, transfer techniques, color processes; studio practice, lectures, discussions, and critiques.

name: INTRODUCTION TO VIDEO, PERFORMANCE & INSTALLATION ART
subject: Art Department
description: An introduction to time-based art forms including video, installation, and visual art performance.
requisite: Requisites: ART107 and (ART100, 108 or 208) or declared in an Art graduate program

name: INTERMEDIATE PAINTING I
subject: Art Department
description: Development of technical processes, concepts, historical continuity. Study and application of various media of oils, acrylics, collage materials.
requisite: Requisites: ART222 or declared in an Art graduate program

name: CERAMICS II
subject: Art Department
description: Continued investigation into forming; hand-building, throwing, slip-casting, press molding; with emphasis on individual form concepts. Glazing, decorating, firing techniques including reduction, oxidation and primitive methods.
requisite: Requisites: ART224 or declared in an Art graduate program

name: ETCHING
subject: Art Department
description: Introduction to intaglio printmaking techniques. Studio problems in platemaking and printing.
requisite: Requisites: (ART102, 112, 212, 232, 306, 316, or 336) or declared in an Art graduate program

name: LIFE DRAWING II
subject: Art Department
description: Further investigation into anatomical structure and intrinsic forms involved in drawing from different models. Development of concepts and technique.
requisite: Requisites: ART232 or declared in an Art graduate program

name: INTRO TO RESPONSIVE WEB DESIGN
subject: Art Department
description: Introduction to user-centered, responsive web design for mobile, tablet, and laptop. Write HTML, CSS, and Javascript directly to design and develop fully responsive websites.
requisite: Requisites: (ART102 or 107), 346, and ART438 or concurrent enrollment in ART438, or declared in (MFA-Art or MS Design + Innovation)

name: SERIGRAPHY
subject: Art Department
description: Materials and techniques of silk screen process; silk screen as a fine art form.
requisite: Requisites: (ART102, 112, 212, 222, 232, 306, 316, or 326) or declared in an Art graduate program

name: SERVICE LEARNING IN ART
subject: Art Department
description: Students discuss community-based practices in the field, and will work with a community partner in an art-related capacity.

name: SOUND DESIGN FOR THE PERFORMING AND VISUAL ARTS
subject: Art Department
description: Production of audio soundtracks to complement the work of artists. The relationship of sound and music to dance, video, film, computer art, and other interdisciplinary forms.
requisite: Requisites: Declared in an Art, Dance, or Communication Arts program

name: WATERCOLOR II
subject: Art Department
description: Continued investigations in watercolor and mixed media works on paper with goal of development of concepts and technical skill.
requisite: Requisites: ART242 or declared in an Art graduate program

name: METAL FABRICATION AND WELDING IN SCULPTURE
subject: Art Department
description: Reviews common welding and metal fabrication techniques available to artists, including various welding processes, brazing techniques, torch work, cutting devices, bending methods, and finishing techniques.  Mild steel will be the primary material of exploration.
requisite: Requisites: (ART214 or 244) or declared in an Art graduate program

name: BASIC GRAPHIC DESIGN
subject: Art Department
description: Introduces the basic principles of graphic design. Develop an initial understanding of formal, conceptual, and technical aspects of the field. Emphasis will be given to the importance of working process, presentation and craftsmanship.
requisite: Requisites: (ART102 or 107) and declared in Art , Art Education, Certificate in Art Studio, or Certificate in Graphic Design; or declared in Art MFA or Design + Innovation MS

name: INTRODUCTION TO DIGITAL PRINTMAKING
subject: Art Department
description: Provides students with fundamental skills in combining had printed and digital output.  Hybrid print integrates laser plate, monoprint, collograph, stencil, stamping, and embossment with inkjet output.  Focuses on enhancement of digital output through integration of hand printed elements.
requisite: Requisites: (ART102, 107, 176, 306, 316, 326, 336, 346, or 376) or declared in an Art graduate program

name: GLASSWORKING
subject: Art Department
description: Glassworking toward a personal concept of material.
requisite: Requisites: (ART104, 214, 224, 244, or 334) or declared in an Art graduate program

name: CODING FOR GRAPHIC DESIGN
subject: Art Department
description: Explore the aesthetic of computational graphic design and typography with physical interaction, sound, data, and digital fabrication.
requisite: Requisites: (ART102 or 107), 346, and ART438 or concurrent enrollment in ART438, or declared in (MFA-Art or MS Design + Innovation)

name: STAGE LIGHTING I
subject: Art Department
description: Application of lighting design to the stage and natural environment. Color principles, lighting instruments, and control equipment. Production participation and labs.

name: SET DESIGN I
subject: Art Department
description: Principles of composition, scale, perspective, and color applied to the stage; production of ground plans, elevations, sketches, and models.

name: PHOTOGRAPHY
subject: Art Department
description: Techniques, philosophies, and concepts in photography as an art form. Emphasis on personal expression and relationship to other media.
requisite: Requisites: (ART100, 102, 104, 107, 108, 176, or 208) or declared in an Art graduate program

name: INTERNSHIPS IN ART
subject: Art Department
description: This online course allows students who have found outside art-related internships to earn academic credit in connection with their work experience.

name: DIGITAL FABRICATION STUDIO
subject: Art Department
description: Introduction to the practice and application of digital fabrication technologies in an artistic context with an emphasis on extending and integrating with traditional material approaches to art production. Includes theoretical readings devoted to the implications of digital and machine technologies on art practice.
requisite: Requisites: ART107 or declared in an Art graduate program

name: ART FOUNDRY
subject: Art Department
description: Traditional and nontraditional methods of fine art foundry.
requisite: Requisites: (ART104, 214, 224, 244, 314, 334, 343, or 354), or declared in an Art graduate program

name: DIGITAL IMAGING STUDIO
subject: Art Department
description: Explore current and historical practices in the digital fine arts while refining conceptual and technical understanding of digital art forms as powerful tools for generating and communicating images and ideas. Students will create and manipulate both static and moving imagery, with implications for digital drawing, painting, print-making, video editing/post-production, and narrative or non-narrative 2D animation in a fine art context.
requisite: Requisites: (ART107, 176, 318, 429, or 529) or declared in an Art graduate program

name: 3D DIGITAL STUDIO I
subject: Art Department
description: Introduction to three-dimensional modeling in the computer, in particular the use of 3D digital models for the creation of images and objects.
requisite: Requisites: ART107 or declared in an Art graduate program

name: HISTORY OF GRAPHIC DESIGN AND TYPOGRAPHY
subject: Art Department
description: Examines the major developments in graphic design and typography as the fields slowly emerged and began to define themselves during the 19th, 20th, and 21st centuries.
requisite: Requisites: (ART102 or 107), and 346 or concurrent enrollment; or declared in Art MFA or Design + Innovation MS

name: ADVANCED SOUND DESIGN
subject: Art Department
description: Advanced instruction in the production of sound tracks to complement the work of artists in dance, video, film, computer art and other interdisciplinary forms.

name: ICONS, SYMBOLS, AND PICTOGRAMS
subject: Art Department
description: Addresses basic visual communication principles that include semiotics, gestalt, form, and context, and applies them to the design of icons, symbols, and pictograms. Cultural, psychological, social, and historical interpretations of these forms are analyzed through design projects, readings, discussion, and research.

name: SPECIAL TOPICS
subject: Art Department
description: Various beginning-level special topics courses in Art.

name: INTERMEDIATE PAINTING: NEW FIGURATION I
subject: Art Department
description: The human figure as a source for creative and independent viewpoints in painting and other media. Students work together in the painting studio from a live model and from other figural sources.
requisite: Requisites: (ART222, 232 or 322) or declared in an Art graduate program

name: NEON: LIGHT AS SCULPTURE
subject: Art Department
description: Introduction to light as sculptural medium including techniques for creating art using luminous tubes.

name: ILLUSTRATION
subject: Art Department
description: Practice of illustration for commercial printing.
requisite: Requisites: ART102 and (ART212, 232, 312, or 332) or declared in an Art graduate program

name: GRAPHIC DESIGN FOR BRANDING AND IDENTITY
subject: Art Department
description: This is an advanced graphic design course with an emphasis on corporate brand identity development. Topics can include mark development, product packaging, marketing and advertising collateral, web branding, and broadcast advertising development. Special attention is given the application of semiotics and other forms of basic communication theory to the design process.
requisite: Requisites: (ART102 or 107 or declared in an Art graduate program), ART346, and 438

name: INFORMATION GRAPHICS
subject: Art Department
description: This course examines the theory and practice of visual representation of information. Students will learn to create effective and illuminating graphical displays of data based on four basic formulations -- location, time, category, hierarchy, and index.

name: GRAPHIC DESIGN FOR PACKAGING
subject: Art Department
description: Defines the role of packaging in product identification, presentation, and production. The unique challenges of adapting typography, illustration, design and materials to three-dimensional forms are explored. Research includes marketing objectives, structural integrity and display aesthetics.

name: PAPERMAKING: HISTORY, ELEMENTS AND TECHNIQUES
subject: Art Department
description: Investigation and explanation of papermaking by hand as it relates to printmaking, drawing, and sculpture. History of papermaking stressing the last hundred years. Techniques of the craft, traditional sheet forming and use of paper pulp as pure plastic material with same educational goals as metal, ceramics, and wood.

name: GRAPHIC DESIGN FOR POSTERS
subject: Art Department
description: Examines the design of posters as a mode of communication. Students will learn to create effective combinations of words and images that mobilize principles of composition, perception, and rhetoric. Projects will encourage students to further explore graphic design as a means of communication, artistic expression, and information organization.

name: INTERDISCIPLINARY STUDIES IN THE ARTS
subject: Art Department
description: Guest artists will offer interdisciplinary courses on topics appropriate to their specializations.

name: SPECIAL TOPICS IN 4D ART
subject: Art Department
description: Topics courses exploring historical, theoretical and studio components surrounding time-based art forms including digital animation, video, installation, and visual art performance.

name: INTERMEDIATE PHOTOGRAPHY
subject: Art Department
description: Introduction to more advanced printing techniques, large format camera, critical analysis, and discussion of history of photography and current trends.
requisite: Requisites: ART376 and (ART107 or 176) or declared in an Art graduate program

name: ADVANCED RELIEF PRINTMAKING
subject: Art Department
description: Emphasis on color problems, surface qualities; studio practice, discussion, critiques.
requisite: Requisites: ART306 or declared in an Art graduate program

name: MAKING COMICS 2
subject: Art Department
description: Builds on the work begun in Making Comics 1. Students will already be comfortable working on deadline, with applying previous comics-making experience to a variety of story styles, both fictional and non-fictional, and with using a variety of materials. This class is just as rigorous and demanding as ART307. You'll be required to write and draw in your journal every day. Homework is substantial. Students will finish a 3-4 page comic strip each week, even when feeling uninspired. Readings will include more long-form comics. Students will identify a theme present in their own work to be explored through drawing and writing. In the last part of the semester, students will create a 'zine with a focused narrative. It will be an original, reproducible, handmade book of at least 32 pages, comprised of both visual and written elements. Everything created will be drawn, painted and written by hand.

name: COLLOQUIUM IN ART
subject: Art Department
description: Prominent artists, curators  critics present their work through lectures and visual presentations.

name: ART PERFORMANCE
subject: Art Department
description: An exploration of art genres that often incorporate a form of time-based performance, including but not limited to elements found in theater, dance, music, spoken word/poetry, etc.

name: ADVANCED DRAWING I
subject: Art Department
description: Advanced level drawing course taught in a structured format where students work on various problems/issues in drawing.
requisite: Requisites: ART312 and (ART100, 108 or 208) or declared in an Art graduate program

name: ADVANCED SCULPTURE WORKSHOP 1
subject: Art Department
description: Instruction in the use of various materials as required by the individual in terms of the formal and conceptual basis of the work. Emphasis on independent research and development of studio projects.
requisite: Requisites: ART314 or declared in an Art graduate program

name: ADVANCED LITHOGRAPHY
subject: Art Department
description: Development of advanced concepts and techniques in lithography, to include drawing on stone with crayon and tusche, transfer techniques, color processes; studio practice, lectures, discussions, and critiques.
requisite: Requisites: ART316 or declared in an Art graduate program

name: ARTIST'S VIDEO
subject: Art Department
description: Principles and techniques in video art.
requisite: Requisites: (ART208 and 318) or declared in an Art graduate program

name: INSTALLATIONS AND ENVIRONMENTS
subject: Art Department
description: Studio projects in site-specific art making supplemented by readings and examples of relevant contemporary artists' work.
requisite: Requisites: ART214 or declared in an Art graduate program

name: ADVANCED PAINTING I
subject: Art Department
description: Technical processes; emphasis on personal expression, concepts, in various approaches to painting.
requisite: Requisites: (ART322 or 452) or declared in an Art graduate program

name: ADVANCED CERAMICS I
subject: Art Department
description: Thrown and hand-built forms, clay bodies, glazes, firing, general studio procedure; emphasis on development of personal concepts.
requisite: Requisites: ART324 or declared in an Art graduate program

name: ADVANCED TYPOGRAPHY
subject: Art Department
description: An advanced investigation of typography for visual communication and expression. Emphasis is placed on the analysis of meaning as conveyed through, materials, technology, and design. Projects are experimental and are designed to challenge you to expand your understanding of the function typography plays in design, art, and culture.

name: ADVANCED ETCHING/INTAGLIO
subject: Art Department
description: Research in advanced intaglio techniques. Color printing.
requisite: Requisites: ART326 or declared in an Art graduate program

name: DIGITAL INTERACTIVE STUDIO
subject: Art Department
description: Concepts and techniques of digital interactive art with an emphasis on physical interaction.
requisite: Requisites: ART107 or declared in an Art graduate program

name: 3D DIGITAL STUDIO II
subject: Art Department
description: Intermediate/advanced class covering the theory and practice of 3D digital modeling and animation software as a tool for making art.

name: SCREEN PERFORMANCE
subject: Art Department
description: Focuses on performance made for the screen including first person narrative, spoken word, video dance, fictional cinema, experimental documentary and other forms of mediated performance practice.

name: ADVANCED LIFE DRAWING I
subject: Art Department
